Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 2. The Advent of an Extraordinary Lineage
At that time there was a city named Kapilavastu on the banks of the River Ganga, Bhagirathi, the "Chariot of the Fortunate."
Scene working notes: The Vinaya source provides a much more detailed account of the founding of Kapilavastu, which is reproduced in English in Rockhill, pp. 11-12.

Sun of Faith - English: King Simhahanu, descendant of a line of universal monarchs and member of the Shakya clan, reigned over Kapilavastu.
Simhahanu had four sons named Shuddhodana, Shuklodana, Dronodana, and Amrtodana.

Sun of Faith - Tibetan (བོད་ཡིག།): སྲས་མོ་ཡང་། བཞི་སྟེ། གཙང་མ་ཡང་། དཀར་མོ་དང། བྲེ་བོ་མོ་དང། བདུད་རྩི་མོའོ།
Sun of Faith - English: He also had four daughters named Shuddha, Shukla, Drona, and Amrita.
The Shakya king Suprabuddha reigned over the Shakya town Devadaha.
Under these two rulers, the kingdoms were happy and prosperous according to dharma. So did they maintain their kingdoms.
Simhahanu made a wish, "Would it not be fitting if, among my descendents, a universal ruler were to appear?"
Suprabuddha then wished to allign himself with Simhahanu.
An extraordinary daughter was born to Suprabuddha. Everyone said, "She can't be a human girl. She's an illusion created by our good karma.”
She was named Maya, "Illusion," and the diviners prophesied that the son born to her would become a powerful universal ruler.
Later, another daughter even more extraordinary than the first was born to King Suprabuddha's wife.
She was named Mahamaya Devi, "Great Illusion Goddess."
It was prophesied, "A child bearing the thirty-two marks of a great being will be born to her, and he will become a universal ruler."
Some time later, Suprabuddha wrote to King Simhahanu in a letter,
“I have two extraordinary daughters. You may take whichever you please as wife for Shuddhodana.”
Simhahanu replied, “He should take both."
We shall accept the younger. The other will need to be examened at court.”
Mahamaya Devi and her retinue of five hundred were accepted as prince Shuddhodana's wives.

Some time after that, there were some hill-dwelling people who were part of the Pandava royal line, enemies of the Shakyas. Prince Shuddhodana was charged [by his father] with subduing them and the Shakya people agreed to give him a precious gift.
He defeated the Pandavas and when he returned, the Shakya people asked Simhahanu what he precious gift he would like.
The Shakyas had a law that forbids them to take a second wife from the same family.
There was someone extraordinary who was suitable for the prince but she would have been a second wife taken from the same family.
The Shakya court then granted permission and Princess Maya Devi and her entourage of five hundred were taken, along with great spleandor and wealth, as the wives of prince Shuddhodana.
Some time later Simhahanu died.
His eldest son, Shuddhodana, assumed dominion over the kingdom.
His subjects were more prosperous and happy than they had been under the previous king.
